greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of partitions of n into distinct parts, the least being odd.
comment: Also number of partitions of n such that if k is the largest part, then k occurs an odd number of times and each of the numbers 1,2,...,k-1 occurs at least once. Example: a(7)=4 because we have [3,2,1,1], [2,2,2,1], [2,1,1,1,1,1] and [1,1,1,1,1,1,1]. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Mar 29 2006
reference: N. J. Fine, Basic Hypergeometric Series and Applications, Amer. Math. Soc., 1988; p. 56, Eq. (26.28).
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
formula: G.f.: Sum_{ k >= 1 } x^(k*(k+1)/2)/((1+x^k)*Product_{i=1..k} (1-x^i) ). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Aug 10 2004
G.f.: Sum_{k>=1} x^(2k-1)*Product_{j>=2k} (1 + x^j). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Mar 29 2006
maple: g:=sum(x^(2*k-1)*product(1+x^j, j=2*k..60), k=1..60): gser:=series(g, x=0, 55): seq(coeff(gser, x, n), n=0..53); # _Emeric Deutsch_, Mar 29 2006
b:= proc(n, i) option remember; `if`(i*(i+1)/2<n, 0, b(n, i-1)+
mathematica: mx=53; Rest[CoefficientList[Series[Sum[x^(2*k-1) Product[1+x^j, {j, 2*k, mx}], {k, mx}], {x, 0, mx}], x]]  (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Apr 05 2011, after _Emeric Deutsch_ *)
program: p k m = if m < k then 0 else p (k+1) (m-k) + p (k+1+0^(n-m)) m
results.author: _Clark Kimberling_
ext: a(0)=0 prepended by _Alois P. Heinz_, Feb 01 2019
